segments.text: the Americans came to the point where they were acting like, hey, I may disagree with you about whether or not we ought to be here in this war at all or not, but I can't find any excuse at all for torturing American prisoners.
And the, oh,
The North Vietnamese found out about this change in attitude in a number of different ways.

When they did, that meant that they had one of two choices with regard to us, and that was either unite America against them or back off on their efforts to exploit us and try to get out of us what they want.
They backed off somewhat.
They didn't stop completely, and there were a lot of people who got hurt very badly after that period, but it was a whole lot better than it had been before.
For example, take the food, for example.
Before that, what was your staple, the usual type of meal, if you will?
Okay.
Generally, it consisted of either bread or rice.
Earlier in the war,
It was mostly bread.
Later on, it was mostly rice, leading up to the change point that I'm talking about.
That was our staple.
And then we'd have a side dish.
We called it sewer weed.
You'd see it growing along the side of the sewer ditches.
I watched guards out the slats on this first cell that I described that had the shutters on it.
I could see down out of the shutters, and there was a little sewer ditch.
It smelled like a sewer ditch.
They walked along, picked a herd.
lunch right there, boiling.
Appetizing.
It was just different kinds of greens.
That was what the majority of it was.
After the change point, we began to get some protein, some reconstituted milk, some canned meat, some canned beans, things like that with Russian labels on them.

more in the last year or the last six months than earlier on, but after the change point in the late 60s, we began to see some of those things appear when they hadn't before to any substantial degree.
What about the physical treatment of the soldiers?
More threats and less torture.
Before the change point, they come in, yank somebody out of the cell,
and just start torturing them to get a war crimes confession or whatever.
And having the kind of open communications for the classes that we talked about later on would have been unthinkable before that time.
Afterwards, you know, if we were having a meeting, there was a class going on, they'd come in, they'd point their weapons at us, they'd load their weapons,
And they'd rant and rail and threat, threaten a lot.
And they might even take one guy out, but they wouldn't hurt him very badly.
More of a scare tactic.
Yeah, trying to.
And when we found out that things were changing, we adapted accordingly.
Well, that's another thing I wanted to bring up was what kind of, how did you figure out what was the actual true
you know, news and world events versus the propaganda.

I'm sure I've heard that they had the radio playing a lot and you would hear, you know, about the terrible things that were going on in America and the protesters and that nobody was behind you and that kind of a thing.
How did you distinguish between the correct, valid news and what they wanted you to think was going on?
We did a terrible, terrible thing, Barbara.
And one of the interrogators...
observe what was going on and really let one of our guys have it.
And he accused us of listening with our minds.
And the implication was that's the lowest thing you could do.
Even in this kind of war, that's not fair to them.
In their context, that would be unthinkable.
What you hear the party say is the answer you give back when asked.
When we hear what the party said, then when we got pressed to the point where we had to say something, because the pain got so great, we'd tell them what really happened.
Not what they had said, but we got to be very good at reading their propaganda or listening to it
and figuring out what must have really happened.

And we might not ever know exactly for sure, at least not within a short timeframe, but we'd be close enough to give us a more reasonable view of what was happening in the war and in the world and in our country.
How did the news of, again, the anti-war protests
things like that affect you?
Did you think it was greatly exaggerated or did you think maybe they'd made the entire thing up?
Initially, we did think it was greatly exaggerated because that hadn't been going on when people in my vintage of shoot-down were captured.
Later on, it became apparent that there had to be some kind of a very substantial anti-war movement going on in this country.
How did that affect your morale?
Very disappointing.

At the same time, all we had to do was look around a little bit when we were being marched to an interrogation and say, hey, I don't like what the protesters are doing, but I'd sure rather live in a country where you could do that than the way these folks have to live here.
So we talked about the feelings of nationalism really carried a lot of people through there, and they grew and formed a common bond.
That seems to go without saying.
Can you talk a little bit about that?
It was a whole lot easier for us, because in general terms, for us, it was very, very clear who were the good guys and who were the bad guys.
The bad guys made it very clear who they were, and there wasn't any doubt about it.
They wouldn't tolerate
especially for the first five or six years, they wouldn't even tolerate somebody who just didn't constantly bump heads with them, much less somebody who was overtly hostile to them.
And later on, that changed.
Interesting, because I was going to ask you what you thought the difference between
You hear so many people now, you know, writing books or speaking out against the war, and they're very bitter and cynical and jaded and think they've been betrayed.
And then you'll speak to former POWs who say, very patriotic, very nationalistic.
Do you think it's the two experiences that were so different?
Yes.
Very different.
When we came home, we were treated like heroes.
Like...
We just, oh, let's see.
I had to be careful when I came home what I admired.
Because every time I turned around, whatever I admired, somebody would give to me.
People just could not do enough for us.
When the guys who went over there and did the same kind of thing I was doing before I got shot down, whether it was in the air or on the ground or out in the Gulf of Tonkin,
When they came home, they were, in the minds of a lot of people in this country, held in less esteem than the Viet Cong.
What do you think that is?
I don't think there is a simple answer to that question.
I think they were blamed for a lot of things they didn't do.
The media did an abominable job on that war.
As far as the media was concerned in general, whatever the Viet Cong did,
was, oh, whether or not you agreed with their politics, if it was a brave kind of thing, you know, a little guy going up against a big giant, it was heroic.
If they did something that we would consider abominable, it was no less than what was expected from them because they come from a different culture where human life is not held in high regard.
When we...
When we looked cross-eyed, we were condemned for it by the media.
We were fighting in a situation that was unlike anything we had ever run up against before.
We were fighting a communist enemy.
We were fighting an Oriental enemy.
The Orients overpopulated.
Individual lives have not had the importance over there that they have in much of the rest of the world.

You put that combination together, the Orient and communism, and for a mother to take her little baby and stuff a hand grenade in the diaper and have the little baby walk up to the jeep, blow up the jeep and a couple of GIs, to them was a heroic act.
For us to turn around and shoot the mother for doing that,
to keep her from killing a whole bunch more was absolutely unthinkable.
I think that's a bit of a fault in our culture.
And to a degree, the media had picked up on our culture in the way they interpreted things.
But I would say
As far as the Vietnam War was concerned, everything that I have seen that the media did, I would have to categorize as extremely subjective.
There was no objectivity on their part at all.
I was going to ask you this at the end, but I'll go ahead and jump to it.
What do you feel about the, now there's this big media fad, you know, the Vietnam movies, all the Rambo stuff, the TV shows.
Now everybody's a big hero, or it's kind of a display of everybody's personal experiences.
I mean, there's a variety of attitudes about the war now.
Do you feel that any of the films have been accurate, or are they just out to make a buck?
Any of the TV shows?
Why do you think suddenly it's such a big deal?
OK.
I'm not sure why it's such a big deal, but there seems to be a national willingness to go look at it now, when for years we didn't even want to think about it, much less look at it.
Maybe distance?
A little more objective?
Well, there's a new generation that's looking at it now.
And I'm sure that makes a difference.
I don't know how to quantify how much difference it makes.
I'm sure that kind of thing helps.
As far as the quality of what I've seen, in general, the Hollywood and the made-for-TV movies, they are still...
They're still down on Americans.
It's not as, well, it is just about as hostile toward the American GI who fought in Southeast Asia now as the media was when it was going on.
There are a few exceptions.
There are very few.

One of the first that I saw that I thought was good, and these are both connected with the POW thing, and I feel a little more qualified to talk there, but the first one made several years ago was when Hell was in Session, Hal Holbrook playing Jerry Dent.
The second was more recent.
The title of it was Hanoi Hilton.
It's one of the best movies I've ever seen.
not just Vietnam movies, but best movies, and the reason is it was atypical for a Hollywood movie.
There wasn't a John Wayne who would walk in, overcome overwhelming odds, never feel fear or pain, or have a tear in his eye, and ride off into the sunset with just his horse when it was over.
Sylvester Stallone.
Yeah.
It was real people who had some virtues and some weaknesses.
And they were the guys that I knew there who did the best they could with what they had.
They hurt.
They cried.
They had a few victories.
But when it was over, they could still hold their heads up.
And the irony of it was when it was over,
350 American POWs went to war against 17 million North Vietnamese, and the North Vietnamese had all the guns and the leg irons and the handcuffs and the bars and the keys, and we won.
We accomplished what we wanted to do with regard to our relationship to them and to the war.
They failed at what they wanted to do.
with regard to, in respect to their relationship with us and their intentions as to how they were to exploit us for the war.
That got a little bit off the track, but that movie The Hanoi Hilton was, it was really condemned before it ever got out.
Because while she was not named, Jane Fonda in character appeared in the movie
And I don't know whether Jane Fonda just has that many friends or what, but the movie was panned by the critics.
And it shouldn't have been.
I think one of the reasons that it turned out so good was the list of people they had as advisors in the credits.
I knew those guys.
And they listened to the people who were there.
For a change.
Yes, for a change.
Well, let's jump back quickly to the very, very end when finally getting released.
How did you, did you know it was coming?
Did you know that the end was on its way?
By increasing the treatment to where they used to, they were giving you more and more food, trying to make you look a little bit better.
Did you get the hint that okay, the day is coming?
We worked in probabilities and not absolutes.
We used to, among ourselves, jokingly refer to
the anticipation when we would see small or large improvements in our treatment, and the food, the way the guards acted to us, et cetera, we refer to times of improved treatment as peace scares.
Because that seemed to be the way the North Vietnamese looked at it.
Oh my gosh.
We may have to give some of these guys back.
We may have to stop prosecuting the war the way we are now.
that was the reason for the nomenclature.
And we knew that that things had reached a level regarding the potential for our release and proceeded onward that they hadn't reached before.
The way the North Vietnamese were acting toward us, were treating us, etc.
At the same time,
Even after I was on the plane and the rest of the guys felt the same way headed out of Hanoi, we didn't relax and let all our weight down on the airplane until we were out of mid-range.
Because there had been enough false starts and regressions to know that it's not over until it's really over.
So it was a mixed bag.
Tremendous anticipation.
and matching desire, but great restraint.
We've been disappointed so many times.
What about the big reception in Washington, D.C.?
President Nixon?
Talk a little bit about that because I'm vaguely remembering that on television.
What was their overall, maybe of your friends, their attitude towards Nixon as president?
Because again, there was so much protest.
And were you amazed to come back and find so much hostility towards him?
Yeah, I was.
First of all, I guess, like any mortal human being, Nixon's a little bit of a mixed bag.
Some things he did toward the end,
were dumb and shameful.
Specifically with the bombings, perhaps?
No, I'm not talking about the war.
I'm talking about Watergate and those sort of things.
He took a lot of heat over what he did at the end of the war.
He was, at the same time, one of the first people to stand up, bite the bullet, and do what had to be done.
We needed to bomb North Vietnam.
We didn't want to, but that was the source of trouble.
Specifically, we needed to bomb Hanoi, because that was the core of it.
And until we did, the war wasn't going to end.
I wish so much that some of the people who are critical of that sort of thing could be in a war and see what happens.
Because in war, in this war, we were the only one that fought by any rules.
And in general, any enemy you go up against, as far as we're concerned, isn't going to have any rules.
The only rule is win if you can.
When we started bombing North Vietnam, excuse me, when we started bombing Hanoi, the war was over.
And...
Let's see, what was his name, Bonnie, the senior officer?
Flynn, General Flynn.
He was a full colonel when he was shot down.
But he said, when we started hearing the bombs fall on Hanoi, he said, we started packing our bags because we knew we were going home pretty soon, but they didn't stop right away.
Watching the reaction of the North Vietnamese told the whole story of the war in a period of about a week there.

and I guess the most concise description of it is one of the guards who low level interrogator who spoke a little bit of English coming up to one of the barred windows and opening the hatch and looking in at us kind of talking to us but not really talking to us and just

incredulous look demeanor and attitude that had never been there before and basically his words were Nixon's gone crazy he's gonna kill us what had happened up to that point Barbara was North Vietnam had been able to conduct the war
and exactly determine what the consequences of the war to them were going to be at any point along the way.
And if they started feeling a little more discomfort than they wanted to, all they had to do was say, drop some kind of a hint that maybe they'd talk about peace.
We'd stop the bombing in North Vietnam.
We'd give them a chance to resupply in the North.
We'd give them a chance to resupply in the South.
We'd give them a chance to get ready to go all over again, build back up to full strength
And then they'd say, no, we don't like you guys anymore.
We're going to fight some more.
And they played the on-again, off-again game all the way, and their idea was just to drag it out until we got tired of fighting.
Because they weren't getting tired.
Right.
Well, they were getting tired, but they were willing to pay the price.
At least their leaders were willing to keep making them pay the price.
And they didn't really have a whole lot of other options anyway.

the people who were doing the work when President Nixon ordered the bombing of Hanoi he didn't give them the option he took away the option they had had up to that point of deciding what their losses were going to be and he prosecuted the war the way a war ought to be prosecuted at least at that point if you're going to be in it
And that is either you win it or you die trying.
There isn't anything you gain by coming in second in a war.
We didn't want to dominate North Vietnam.
We didn't want to make North Vietnam capitalist or democratic.
All we wanted them to do was stop forcefully exporting what they had.
And when President Nixon started bombing Hanoi,
He took their options away and, in effect, was saying, you guys stop and you end this on terms that are acceptable to us for your history.
No other choices are we going to leave.
As soon as that message was clearly communicated to North Vietnam, of course, Ho Chi Minh had died a few years earlier.
But North Vietnamese leadership just suddenly had 32 chicklets showing between their lips.
And it's, yes, sir, is there anything else we can do for you?
That was their attitude at the negotiating table.
It was their attitude toward us.
Everything else.

And as soon as we, in terms they could understand, which was for us, communicated to them that what they were doing was not going to be tolerated anymore and that the choice was theirs either to die trying it, continue to try it, or stop it and live,
And the rest was just settling the details at that point.
So when you finally met him at the dinner, what did he have to say to you?
Or what possibly did you have to say to him?
Well, I guess our message to him was thank you.
Because he was the one who finally did not only what was necessary to end the war,
at least at that point, and obtain an agreement from them to stop forcing their way on South Vietnam, which was what we had gone over there to do, too.
So it let us win the war, even though we did it in adverse circumstances.
But it also got us home.
No other way would we have come home.
There may have been a few trickle home, like a few guys they let go early.
But they weren't going to let us go home.
Not the entire group.
Two weeks after I got home, Bonnie and I and another Dallas POW and his wife were invited by Congressman Teague, who had
really been a friend to our families.
And my family wasn't even in his district, but he had really been a friend to our families.
He was an Aggie, by the way.
The Teague building is named after him.
Okay.
Congressman Olin Teague.
Something familiar.
Right.
He invited us.
He was Mr.
Veteran.
He was Chairman of the House Veteran Affairs Committee, among other things, as well as the Space Committee.
But he invited us to go with him to the National VFW Convention.
Excuse me.
It was the VFW dinner for Congress.
At that time, he arranged for us to have a tour of the White House.
You know, get the tickets for us, like the congressman can do.
And it was to be a
a private tour for the four of us, a guided tour, rather than a big group thing.
While we were on the tour, obviously what happened behind the scenes was he called the president, said, hey, you got two POWs over there.
So one of the president's staff men located us, said, President Nixon has heard that you're here.
We'd like to have a visit with you in the Oval Office.
So we were escorted in, the four of us, and spent a little over an hour, I guess, in the Oval Office.
While we were there, Henry Kissinger came in.
But we just got to, basically we got to sit down, the four of us, and have a nice talk with President Nixon.
He was a man who had sat in a chair that, I would say,

very few people could sit in and still keep their sanity and maybe sometimes he didn't he had he had probably the most intense and diverse pressures of any recent president anyway he was handed a bucket of worms when he came in i think the the fact of of his election uh the last one
by the margin that it was, indicated that there was certainly a preference of what he was doing to the alternatives, at least as far as the nation was concerned.
And I think that's probably the reason for the idea of the silent majority.
My personal feeling was I think he felt glad to meet a friend.
because that was the way he perceived us, at least compared to a lot of people.
I don't mean a personal friend, but somebody who was friendly toward him instead of finding something about one of his policies to criticize.

And I think he was just a very pulled and torn man during that time who had decided what he thought ought to be done and made some hard decisions to go ahead and do it, even though it was going to be unpopular.
And it might cost him a whole lot more than he'd really like to pay.
And I think it did.
Would you like to talk at all a little bit about, so many people talk about their spiritual background and how within the camps that really got them through.
Would you say that's something that was a necessity for you as you were there?
Or was it something that developed while you were there?
I would say it was something that was almost universally recognized.
There were four men out of all the POWs that I knew, and I got to know almost all of them to some degree, who were professing atheists.
The rest had some kind of profession of faith in God, as I know him as a Christian.
Most were Christian.
There were a few Jews.
God was openly acknowledged, openly prayed to, and jointly prayed to.
And there's absolutely no doubt in my mind, Barbara, that he's the one who protected us, who kept us alive,
who even though he didn't give us as much as we would have liked to eat at times, he gave us enough to keep us alive.
And enabled us to win the kind of victory I talked about a while ago where there was 17 million of them, 350 of us, and it wasn't even a fair fight for the North Vietnamese.
We had about a number.
That kind of thing
There were just too many things that would have forced other results than what we saw.
The North Vietnamese wanted nothing more of us than to get out of us what they could and kill us in the slowest, most painful way possible and cause grief to ourselves and our family and our nation.
They caused a lot of grief, but they lost their objective.
Would you ever, or have you, considered going back to visit?
I know a lot of the, some of the vets and POWs go back for various reasons.
Have you ever considered it or do you want to someday?
I didn't leave anything there that I need.
I, at least up to this point, as long as I'm given the choice, I would choose not to go back.
it's still a dangerous place to be.
And it's got a lot of memories that having once dealt with them, I'm happier and healthier leaving them alone.
Yeah.
Would you, if you were, from your personal opinion, going to recommend, say,
several books that would, in your opinion, accurately describe the experience.
What would those be?
There have been so many written.
For the interested scholar, what, in your opinion, would be a good thing to read?
Okay, there are a lot of them that I have not read.
I have not, those that I have read, I haven't read any bad ones.

The ones that I've appreciated the most were In the Presence of Mine Enemies by Harold Rutledge, Passing of the Night by Robbery Reisner, With God in a POW Camp by Ralph Gaither, and the one that I just referred to you, In Love and War by Jim and Sybil Stockdale.
I would say from a historical point of view, the book by Jim and Sybil Stockdale would be the most useful.
They are both very active, very intelligent people and are able to
to be more objective than most could be about things that impacted upon them so personally and so intensely.
Okay.
Well, good.
There's so many to choose from.
Thank you very much.
I appreciate it.
You're welcome, Barbara.
